College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Northwest Normal University Lanzhou Gansu 730070 China By immobilizing complexes on the surface of phosphorus-containing polymeric ionic liquids (PILs-PPh3), heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts was realized, which promoted the design combination of the advantages of heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts. Furthermore, the addition of ionic liquid can increase the designability of the phosphine ligand, ranging from the pore structure to acid-base adjustability. In this study, a series of PILs-PPh3 were successfully prepared by copolymerization. The PILs-PPh3 were characterized by scanning electron microscopy, thermogravimetry, and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. Heterogenized homogeneous Rh@PILs-PPh3 catalysts were synthesized by immobilizing Rh(CO)2(acac) on PILs-PPh3, which was used not only as a support but also as a ligand. Furthermore, the Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 catalyst was characterized using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy. The FT-IR and XPS results showed that Rh1 species were present on the Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 catalyst. Moreover, the catalytic performance of Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 was investigated for the hydroformylation of 2,5-dihydrofuran. The effects of the amount of catalyst, mole ratio of reactants, and partial pressure ratio on the reaction were investigated. Undoubtedly, the prepared supported catalyst exhibited good thermal stability and potential applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Polymeric ionic liquids Hydroformylation Rhodium Dihydrofurans 1 Introduction The hydroformylation of alkenes is one of the most extensive processes in the industrial application of catalysis, which allows for the conversion of alkenes to aldehydes using hydrogen and carbon monoxide in one catalytic step [1–3]. Because of its “atomic economy” and environmental friendliness, hydroformylation has become a bridge for the close combination of green chemistry and the petrochemical industry, and it is also one of the important strategies at present for the high-value utilization of C1 resources [4–6]. Dinotefuran, as a nicotine insecticide without chlorine atoms and aromatic rings, was first developed by the Mitsui Chemical Company of Japan, and is quite different from the existing nicotine insecticides in chemical structure and has better performance than neonicotinoid insecticides [7–9]. 3-Formyltetrahydrofuran has been widely applied as an important intermediate in the preparation of dinotefuran. However, there are few reports on the preparation of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran. Researchers deeply concerned on homogeneous systems, and the ligands mainly included phosphine-phosphite ligands [10–12]. Even more unfortunate is that there are some shortcomings in the previous technology for preparing 3-formyltetrahydrofuran: in the cobalt-catalyzed reaction system, there are some disadvantages, such as high reaction pressure, long reaction time, and low product yield; in the rhodium-catalyzed homogeneous reaction system, the reaction time is long; and in the rhodium-catalyzed system, rhodium cannot be recycled, although the product yield is high [13]. Organic ligands such as triphenylphosphine have important applications in the rhodium-catalyzed hydroformylation of olefins, but their application range is limited because of the difficulty of recycling. How to realize heterogeneity of metal complexes is crucial for solving this limitation and prelimininary progress has been achieved [14]. Phosphorus-containing polymeric ionic liquids (PILs-PPh3), which act as both supporters and ligands, have the characteristics of ionic liquid nano-microstructures [15], as well as modifiability, acid-base adjustability, thermal stability, chemical stability, easy separation from the reaction system, and effective inhibition of active center aggregation. In addition, the phosphorus-containing polymeric ionic liquid can make full use of the surface and pore structure of the carrier to achieve a synergistic catalytic effect, thus reducing the amount of catalyst. Furthermore, the structure induction potential of anions in ionic liquids may also be very remarkable [16,17]. Herein, we synthesized a series of porous PILs-PPh3 based on the preparation of polymer ionic liquids by our research group [18]. It is worth noting that the PILs-PPh3 act as both supporters and ligands. A heterogeneous catalyst prepared by metal precursor treatment was used to prepare 3-formyltetrahydrofuran by the hydroformylation of 2,5-dihydrofuran (2,5-DHF), and the catalytic activity of this new catalyst was studied. In addition, the effects of catalyst amount, reactant mole ratio, reaction time, reaction temperature, and partial pressure ratio (CO:H2) on the reaction were investigated. Subsequently, the catalyst was characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller [BET] method), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and thermogravimetric (TG) analysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials The solvents were purified according to the standard laboratory methods. Tetrahydrofuran and toluene were distilled over Na/benzophenone. Absolute ethyl alcohol was distilled over calcium oxide. The chemicals 1-vinylimidazole (>99 wt%, Innochem), 1-iodobutane (98 wt%, Innochem), 1,4-butane sultone (>98 wt%, EnergyChemical), 4-(diphenylphosphino) styrene (97 wt%, Aldrich), divinylbenzene (80 wt%, Energy Chemical), Rh(CO)2(acac) (>99 wt%, Innochem), azodiisobutyro-nitrile, and 2,5-DHF (98 wt%, Innochem), were used directly without purification. 2.2 Catalysts preparation method 2.2.1 Synthesis of phosphorus-containing polymeric ionic liquids (PILs-PPh3) In a 250 mL round-bottom flask, 1-iodobutane (1.0 mol, 184.0 g) was added to a solution of 1-vinylimidazole (1.0 mol, 94.1 g) in anhydrous toluene (100 mL) with constant stirring, and then heated from room temperature to 60 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the formed solid zwitterions ([VIMBt]I) were centrifuged, washed with anhydrous toluene (100 mL × 3), and dried for 12 h in vacuum before further characterization. A similar method was used to prepare 1-vinyl-3-sulfonic butyl imidazolium zwitterions (VIMBs) [18]. [VIMBt]I. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O): δ 9.11 (s, 1H), 7.78 (s, 1H), 7.56 (d, J = 31.6 Hz, 1H), 7.26–7.00 (m, 1H), 5.79 (d, J = 15.5 Hz, 1H), 5.39 (s, 1H), 4.22 (s, 2H), 1.84 (s, 2H), 1.29 (s, 2H), 0.86 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, D2O): δ 12.76, 18.83, 31.13, 19.74, 109.34, 119.43, 122.91, 128.27, 134.11. VIMBs.1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O): δ 8.94 (s, 1H), 7.64 (t, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 7.46 (t, J = 1.7 Hz, 1H), 6.99 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 5.65 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H), 5.27 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H), 4.15 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 2.89–2.70 (m, 2H), 2.01–1.81 (m, 2H), 1.69–1.49 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, D2O): δ 20.97, 27.78, 49.25, 49.99, 109.24, 119.39, 122.93, 128.21, 134.42. Elem. Anal. calcd for C9H14N2O3S: C, 46.94; H, 6.13; N, 12.17; S, 13.92. Found: C, 47.12; H, 6.01; N, 12.15; S, 14.06. The PILs-PPh3 were prepared according to methods described in the literature with slight modifications [19–24]. First, [VIMBt]I (0.02 mol, 5.6 g) was separately dissolved in absolute ethanol (50 mL). Then, 4-(diphenylphosphino) styrene (0.02 mol, 5.8 g), divinylbenzene (0.02 mol, 2.6 g) and azodiisobutyro- nitrile (3.2 wt%) were added at room temperature with constant stirring. The reaction was performed with constant stirring and a N2 atmosphere for 24 h at 80 °C. The solution was filtered, thoroughly washed with diethyl ether (50 mL × 3), and the product was dried under vacuum for further characterization (VIMBtDVB-PPh3). As shown in Scheme 1 , VIMBsDVB-PPh3 was synthesized using a similar method. Furthermore, VIMBt-PPh3 and VIMBs-PPh3 were prepared without divinylbenzene. Elem. VIMBsDVB-PPh3 (white powder): C, 71.12; H, 6.14; N, 4.08; S, 4.36. Anal. Calcd for VIMBsDVB-PPh3 as above: C, 72.2; H, 6.37; N, 4.32; S, 4.94. VIMBt-PPh3 (pale yellow powder): C, 63.01; H, 6.04; N, 4.86. Anal. Calcd for VIMBt-PPh3 as above: C, 61.49; H, 5.69; N, 4.95. VIMBs-PPh3 (white powder): C, 67.12; H, 5.91; N, 5.17; S, 6.06. Anal. Calcd for VIMBs-PPh3 as above: C, 67.16; H, 6.03; N, 5.40; S, 6.18. 2.2.2 Synthesis of PILs-PPh3-supported catalyst Rh@PILs-PPh3 Rh@PILs-PPh3 catalysts were prepared according to previously described methods [25]. PILs-PPh3 (1 mmol, 570 mg) was added to 50 mL THF containing Rh(CO)2(acac) (0.2 mmol, 51.7 mg) and then stirred at room temperature for 24 h in a N2 atmosphere. Then, the catalyst was centrifuged, washed thoroughly with THF, and dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. The loading level of Rh in the catalyst before and after the hydroformylation reaction was measured using the inductively coupled plasma (ICP) method. 2.3 Catalysts characterization FT-IR spectra with a scanning range of 400–4000 cm−1 were acquired using a Nicolet NEXUS 870 system (USA). The particle size and morphology of the samples were recorded by SEM using a Hitachi SU8020 equipment (Tokyo, Japan). TG analysis was performed using a Netzsch STA449F3 simultaneous thermal analysis system (Selb, Germany) between 50 °C and 700 °C in a N2 atmosphere. The BET isotherms were determined using a Micromeritics ASAP2010 instrument (USA). The pore size and volume distributions were calculated using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) technique and the BET method was used to estimate the surface areas. Elemental microanalysis was performed using a Vario EL cube system (Elementar Analysensysteme, Germany). The XPS spectra were obtained using an ESCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with Al Kα X-rays as the excitation source. The ICP spectroscopy was performed using an Agilent 725-ES instrument. The abreaction-corrected HAADF-STEM images were obtained on a FEI-Talos F200s and FEI Super-X EDS Detector equipped. Solid-state 31P MAS NMR spectra was carried out on a Bruker Avance NEO 400 MHz. 2.4 Catalysts activity tests Catalytic activity evaluation experiments were performed in a 100 mL stainless-steel autoclave equipped with a mechanical stirrer. The catalyst, solvent, and 2,5-DHF were added to the high-pressure reactor, which was then sealed. The air in the reactor was replaced with 2.0 MPa N2 three times, and then filled with a gas mixture (CO/H2). The reaction mixture in the reactor was preheated to the desired temperature before starting the reaction, the mechanical stirrer was turned on, and the time was recorded. After the reaction, the catalysts were removed from the system by centrifugation and analyzed using GC (Agilent 7820). Quantitative analysis of 2,5-DHF and 3-formyltetrahydrofuran by GC was performed using n-heptane as the internal standard for the samples. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization 3.1.1 FT-IR analysis The FT-IR spectra of the supported catalysts Rh@PILs-PPh3 are shown in Fig. 1. The peaks at 3049.9 cm−1, 1516.4 cm−1, and 1435.1 cm−1 were attributed to imidazole C-H and C=N stretching vibrations (Fig. 1(a)) [26,27]. In addition, the peak at 2922.5 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibrations of the aromatic C-H ring. The infrared spectrum shows that Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 contains a CO group (1971.9 cm−1) and acetylacetone (1569.9 cm−1, Fig. 1a), indicating that Rh(CO)2(acac) was successfully supported on VIMBtDVB-PPh3 and a part of Rh(CO)2(acac) was adsorbed on the porous structure of polymers. The peaks at 3066.8 cm−1 and 1433.3 cm−1 were attributed to imidazole C-H and C=N stretching vibrations (Fig. 1(b)). The peak at 2921.0 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibrations of the aromatic C-H ring. The peaks at 1179.7 and 1035.6 cm−1 were characteristic of –SO3H [28]. In addition, the IR spectrum indicated that Rh@VIMBsDVB-PPh3 contains the CO group (2061.1 cm−1). Therefore, For these Rh@PILs-PPh3 of one CO group by P atom from the ligands to give Rh(acac)(CO)P can be proposed. 3.1.2 SEM studies Scanning electron microscopy images of the four PILs-PPh3 are illustrated in Fig. 2. It was found that the VIMBtDVB-PPh3 and VIMBsDVB-PPh3 synthesized with divinylbenzene as the cross-linker agent presented relatively regular small spheres with sizes of approximately 0.2 µm. The particles were connected to each other without distinct boundaries, indicating the presence of abundant pores. In addition, VIMBtDVB-PPh3 and VIMBsDVB-PPh3 were weakly agglomerated, and the polymer without divinylbenzene showed that VIMBt-PPh3 and VIMBs-PPh3 were quite agglomerated. One possible reason is that divinylbenzene has a distinctive structure with two vinyl groups in the para position, which acts as a “bridge” between linear molecules. During the reaction, a large number of linear molecules can be bonded and cross-linked to form porous materials [29]. 3.1.3 TG analysis The thermal stability of PILs-PPh3 was determined by the TG method, and weight losses are shown in Fig. 3. Owing to the release of adsorbed water and solvent up to 100 °C, as well as the confinement of the monomer of the polymer inside some pore channels, weight loss occurred in the first stage. However, a drastic decrease in weight loss of polymeric ionic liquids was observed from 300 °C to 460 °C. The observed slight slope between 300 °C and 360 °C may be attributed to the decomposition of the polymeric ionic liquids. The results show that PILs-PPh3 have superior thermal stability and are suitable as supporters and ligands. 3.1.4 BET isotherms As shown in Fig. 4, BET analysis demonstrated a hysteresis loop at a relative pressure P/P0 = 0.2–1.0, indicating that the VIMBtDVB-PPh3 is filled with mesopores. In addition, the BET surface area, pore volume, and BJH average pore size of VIMBtDVB-PPh3 were 62.1 m2/g, 0.2 cm3/g, and 6.14 nm, respectively (Table 1 ). The results showed that VIMBtDVB-PPh3 possessed a relatively high surface area and comparatively large pore volume. The other PILs-PPh3, however, were typically type IV with hysteresis loops at the pressures P/P0 = 0.6–1.0, which is different from macroporous materials. In addition, it can be seen that the PILs-PPh3 prepared by adding divinylbenzene as a cross-linking agent had a larger BET surface area, total pore volume, and average pore width than those prepared without divinylbenzene. 3.1.5 XPS and HAADF-STEM analysis The electronic configurations of the Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 complex were examined by XPS. First, the binding energies of the Rh3d electrons in Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 were measured to be 309.1 and 313.9 eV for Rh3d5/2 and Rh3d3/2, respectively, which indicated that the chemical state of the Rh species was maintained as +1. These values were lower than those of the precursor Rh(CO)2(acac) (309.7 and 314.4 eV). However, the P2p binding energy of Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 (132.6 eV) was greater than that of the parent VIMBtDVB-PPh3 (132.2 eV), which confirmed the coordination between the Rh and P species in VIMBtDVB-PPh3 (Fig. 5a–d). In addition, FT-IR spectral analysis showed that Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 contained a CO group (1971.9 cm−1) and acetylacetone (1569.9 cm−1, Fig. 1a). Considering that Rh+ is a square-planar low-spin d8 metal ion, the corresponding complex is an exception to the 18-electron rule, and is a 16-electron complex [30]. Accordingly, we can infer that the structure of Rh species in Rh@PILs-PPh3 is that each Rh ion is coordinated with one CO group, one phosphorus ligand, and one acac compound. To further investigate the exposure of nitrogen and phosphorous, we performed HAADF-STEM characterization and the results showed that the two kinds of monomers (ILs and phosphine) were uniformly distributed in the polymers. It was also found that the Rh atom was also uniformly distributed in Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 (Fig. 5e, f). 3.2 Performance of the synthesized Rh@PILs-PPh3 catalysts Hydroformylation of 2,5-DHF was used as a probe reaction to evaluate and compare the catalytic performance of Rh@PILs-PPh3. Under homogeneous conditions, the effects of various catalysts on the hydroformylation of 2,5-DHF were studied under the following conditions: molar ratio of 2,5-DHF to Rh of 4412, CO/H2=1:1 (4.0 MPa), 70 °C, and 8 h. The results are presented in Table 2 . When Rh(CO)2(acac) was used as the catalyst and triphenylphosphine, diphenylvinylphosphine, diphenyl (p-vinylphenyl)-phosphine were used as ligands, the conversion of 2,5-DHF was 42.8%–82.0%, the selectivity of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran was more than 94% (Table 2, entries 1–4). In contrast, under heterogeneous reaction conditions, a molar ratio of 2,5-DHF to Rh of 4412, CO/H2 = 1:1 (4.0 MPa), 70 °C, and 8 h, Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 containing an anion (I−), as well as copolymerized by adding divinylbenzene, revealed moderate catalytic activities (Table 2, entry 7), the conversion of 2,5-DHF was 54.2%, the selectivity of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran was 97.6%, and the total selectivity of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran and 2-formyltetrahydrofuran was 99.0%. When Rh@VIMBsDVB-PPh3 was used as the catalyst, the conversion of 2,5-DHF was 42.7%, the selectivity of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran was 94.7%, and the total selectivity of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran and 2-formyltetrahydrofuran was 97.2%. Therefore, we can find that Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 containing an anion (I−) showed preferable catalytic activity when Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 and Rh@VIMBsDVB-PPh3 were used as the catalyst, respectively. Similarly, Rh@VIMBt-PPh3 containing an anion (I−) exhibited better catalytic activity by comparing the Rh@VIMBt-PPh3 and Rh@VIMBs-PPh3. Therefore, the anion (I−) of the polymeric ionic liquids may be an important factor affecting the catalytic activity. In addition, the pore structure of the catalyst may also be a factor affecting the catalytic activity. The 31P MAS NMR spectrum exhibits an additional small peak at 24.0 ppm corresponding to an oxidation state of phosphorus (P=O) (Fig. 6), indicating slight oxidation of P atoms during the polymerization. Therefore, the decrease in catalytic activity compared with that in the homogeneous catalyst system, may be caused by the oxidation of P3+in the preparation process, a change in the ligand structure, a change in the Rh-P coordination mode, or a decrease in the number of phosphine ligands, resulting in a decrease in the number of catalytic active centers. In addition, in a solvent-free or water environment, the conversion of 2,5-DHF was only 21.2–42.1% (Table 2, entries 11, 12) with Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 used as a catalyst. Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 was selected as the catalyst to further explore the influence of various reaction factors, and the results are summarized in Table 3 . The amount of catalyst was determined as one of the main parameters; in accordance with the increase in the amount of catalyst, the conversion of 2,5-DHF increased steadily from 38.4% to 55.1%. However, the selectivity of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran remained almost unchanged. Temperature also affects the catalytic activity of Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3; when the reaction temperature was increased from 50 °C to 80 °C, the conversion of 2,5-DHF improved from 42.7% to 56.1%, and the selectivity of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran decreased from 98.4% to 91.7%. The effect of the reaction time was investigated (Table 3, entries 5–7). With an increase in the reaction time, the conversion of 2,5-DHF increased to 54.8%, whereas the selectivity of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran decreased slightly from 98.1% to 97.2%. Moreover, the partial pressures of CO and H2 were also investigated, and the corresponding results are exhibited in Table 3 (entries 11–15). When the total pressure was maintained at 4.0 MPa and the partial pressure of CO increased gradually, the conversion of 2,5-DHF first increased and then basically remained stable. In addition, when the total pressure was increased from 2.0 MPa to 6.0 MPa, the conversion of 2,5-DHF increased to 56.8% and then decreased slightly (54.3%), and the selectivity of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran decreased from 97.8% to 91.6%. Under optimum conditions, the scope and limitations of the Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 catalyst for the hydroformylation of various olefins were investigated using 2,3-DHF and four other real examples of industrially relevant transformations (Table 4 ). It was found that the Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 catalytic system has a specific range of applicability. When long-chain 1-heptene and 1-octene were used as substrates, olefin conversion was 64.9% and 66.1%, respectively, and the selectivity was more than 99%. When cycloolefin was used as the substrate, the conversion of cyclohexene was 61.5%, and the selectivity was 92.7%. The hydroformylation conversion of cyclooctene was 55.4%, and the selectivity was 99.6%. 3.3 Recyclability of the catalysts The reusability of the Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 catalyst for the hydroformylation of 2,5-DHF was investigated under the optimized reaction conditions (Fig. 7). After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction solution by a simple centrifugation process. After being reused five times, the conversion of 2,5-DHF declined from 54.2% to 38.5%, and the selectivity of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran decreased slightly from 97.6% to 94.8%. ICP-AES analysis indicated leaching of the Rh of Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 in the reaction solution. The results showed that the amount of Rh leaching was approximately 11.3% after the fifth run. A small amount of Rh species was leached into the solution, which may have led to a decrease in the conversion of 2,5-DHF. The structure of the catalyst after five times of reuse was compared with that of fresh Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 using FT-IR analysis (Fig. 8) and XPS (Fig. 9). It is apparent that the coordination between Rh and the ligand species in the catalyst was maintained after five repeated uses. Admittedly, the reuse of the catalyst is slightly poor, and further research is required. 3.4 Hot filtration experiment The hot filtration experiment on the Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 was performed using toluene as solvent (Fig. 10). After a period of reaction, we conducted a hot filtration experiment, and then the reaction solution and the original reaction are monitored. The results showed that the reaction was no further reacted after 2 h, the reaction conversion of 2,5-DHF remained at about 24%, and the selectivity of 3-formyltetrahydrofuran was about 95%, which proved the heterogeneity of the catalyst and the contribution of homogeneous catalyst to the reaction was not obvious. 3.5 Catalytic reaction mechanism The proposed mechanism for the Rh-catalyzed hydroformylation of 2,5-DHF is presented in Scheme 2 [31–34]. Through path 1, hydroformylation products (3-formyltetrahydrofuran) is produced. In path 2, similar to path 1, the isomerization of intermediates D and I is controlled by the equilibrium between two hydrogenated rhodium olefins, which is achieved by inserting or eliminating hydrogen. Furthermore, the formation of the 3-Rh intermediate (D) was demonstrated to be thermodynamically advantageous, although the carbonylation rate of the 2-Rh species (I) was faster than that of the 3-Rh species. In addition, compared with other reported hydroformylation of 2,5-dihydrofuran by heterogeneous catalytic, Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 exhibited some advantages in terms of catalyst dosage, reaction time and regioselectivity (Table 5 ). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the addition of ionic liquid can increase the designability of phosphine ligands, ranging from the pore structure to acid-base adjustability. We synthesized four kinds of phosphorus-containing polymeric ionic liquid-supported rhodium catalysts for the hydroformylation of 2,5-DHF. In particular, Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 exhibited the highest catalytic activity, giving a high selectivity (97.6%) and moderate conversion (54.2%) for the hydroformylation of 2,5-DHF under optimal conditions. In addition, the properties of the catalysts were characterized in detail by FT-IR spectroscopy, XPS, BET isotherms, SEM, and TG analysis. In summary, it was demonstrated that phosphorus-containing polymeric ionic liquid-supported rhodium catalysts may be significant and promising catalysts for the hydroformylation of dihydrofuran. coredata.dc:description: By immobilizing complexes on the surface of phosphorus-containing polymeric ionic liquids (PILs-PPh3), heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts was realized, which promoted the design combination of the advantages of heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts. Furthermore, the addition of ionic liquid can increase the designability of the phosphine ligand, ranging from the pore structure to acid-base adjustability. In this study, a series of PILs-PPh3 were successfully prepared by copolymerization. The PILs-PPh3 were characterized by scanning electron microscopy, thermogravimetry, and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. Heterogenized homogeneous Rh@PILs-PPh3 catalysts were synthesized by immobilizing Rh(CO)2(acac) on PILs-PPh3, which was used not only as a support but also as a ligand. Furthermore, the Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 catalyst was characterized using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy. The FT-IR and XPS results showed that Rh1 species were present on the Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 catalyst. Moreover, the catalytic performance of Rh@VIMBtDVB-PPh3 was investigated for the hydroformylation of 2,5-dihydrofuran. The effects of the amount of catalyst, mole ratio of reactants, and partial pressure ratio on the reaction were investigated. Undoubtedly, the prepared supported catalyst exhibited good thermal stability and potential applications.
coredata.dc:title: Phosphorus-containing polymeric ionic liquids-supported rhodium catalyst for hydroformylation of dihydrofurans
